title: Fraction Division
text: To divide fractions, we multiply the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second.
speech: To divide fractions, we multiply the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second.
pacedSpeech: To divide fractions, we multiply the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second.

title: Reciprocal
speech: The reciprocal of , a over b,  is  b over a .
pacedSpeech: The reciprocal of  , a over b,
is   b over a

title: Reciprocal of the Second Fraction
speech: What is the reciprocal of  5 sixths ?
pacedSpeech: What is the reciprocal of   5 sixths

title: Multiplying Fractions
text: The next step is to multiply the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second.
speech: The next step is to multiply the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second.
pacedSpeech: The next step is to multiply the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second.

title: Determining the Sign
text: Since the signs are the same, the product is positive.
speech: Since the signs are the same, the product is positive.
pacedSpeech: Since the signs are the same, the product is positive.

title: Multiplying Fractions
text: To multiply fractions, we multiply the numerators and the denominators. So the numerator is $$2\times6$$ and the denominator is $$3\times5$$. The next step is to simplify the fraction if possible.
speech: To multiply fractions, we multiply the numerators and the denominators. So the numerator is , 2 times 6  and the denominator is  3 times 5 . The next step is to simplify the fraction if possible.
pacedSpeech: To multiply fractions, we multiply the numerators and the denominators. So the numerator is  , 2 times 6
and the denominator is   3 times 5
. The next step is to simplify the fraction if possible.

title: Checking for Common Factors
text: Do $$2\times6$$ and $$3\times5$$ have any common factors?
speech: Do , 2 times 6  and  3 times 5  have any common factors?
pacedSpeech: Do  , 2 times 6
and   3 times 5
have any common factors?

title: Common Factors
text: We will rewrite $$2\times6$$ and $$3\times5$$ as the product of primes and divide out the common factors from there.
speech: We will rewrite , 2 times 6  and  3 times 5  as the product of primes and divide out the common factors from there.
pacedSpeech: We will rewrite  , 2 times 6
and   3 times 5
as the product of primes and divide out the common factors from there.

title: Rewriting the Numerator
text: What is $$2\times6$$ written as the product of primes?
speech: What is  2 times 6,  written as the product of primes?
pacedSpeech: What is   2 times 6,
written as the product of primes?

title: Rewriting the Denominator
text: What is $$3\times5$$ written as the product of primes?
speech: What is  3 times 5,  written as the product of primes?
pacedSpeech: What is   3 times 5,
written as the product of primes?

title: Dividing Common Factors
text: We can now divide out the common factor $$3$$ from both the top and the bottom, which gives us the fraction $$\frac{2\times2}{5}=\frac{4}{5}$$.
speech: We can now divide out the common factor  3  from both the top and the bottom, which gives us the fraction , fraction, 2 times 2, over 5,  is equal to 4 fifths .
